#Text=Chapter 56 .
#Text=The Sick Ox
#Text=The Thunder Moon passed quickly by ; the hay was in ; the barley partly so .
#Text=Day by day the whitefaced oxen toiled at the creaking yoke , as the loads of hay and grain were jounced cumbrously over roots and stumps of the virgin fields .
#Text=Everything was promising well , when , as usual , there came a thunderbolt out of the clear sky .
#Text=Buck , the off ox , fell sick .
#Text=Those who know little about cattle have written much of the meek and patient ox .

#Text=Those who know them well tell us that the ox is the “ most cussedest of all cussed ” animals ; a sneak , a bully , a coward , a thief , a shirk , a schemer ; and when he is not in mischief he is thinking about it .
#Text=The wickedest pack mule that ever bucked his burden is a pinfeathered turtle-dove compared with an average ox .
#Text=There are some gentle oxen , but they are rare ; most are treacherous , some are dangerous , and these are best got rid of , as they mislead their yoke mates and mislay their drivers .
#Text=Van 's two oxen , Buck and Bright , manifested the usual variety and contrariety of disposition .

#Text=They were all right when well handled , and this Rolf could do better than Van , for he was “ raised on oxen , ” and Van 's over voluble , sputtering , Dutch-English seemed ill comprehended of the massive yoke beasts .
#Text=The simpler whip-waving and fewer orders of the Yankee were so obviously successful that Van had resigned the whip of authority and Rolf was driver .

#Text=Ordinarily , an ox driver walks on the hew ( nigh or left ) side , near the head of his team , shouting “ gee ” ( right ) , “ haw ” ( left ) , “ get up , ” “ steady , ” or “ whoa ” ( stop ) , accompanying the order with a waving of the whip .
#Text=Foolish drivers lash the oxen on the haw side when they wish them to gee -- and vice versa ; but it is notorious that all good drivers do little lashing .
#Text=Spare the lash or spoil your team .
#Text=So it was not long before Rolf could guide them from the top of the load , as they travelled from shook to shook in the field .
#Text=This voice of command saved his life , or at least his limb , one morning , for he made a misstep that tumbled him down between the oxen and the wagon .
#Text=At once the team started , but his ringing “ Whoa ! ” brought them to a dead stop , and saved him ; whereas , had it been Van 's “ Whoa ! ”
#Text=it would have set them off at a run , for every shout from him meant a whip lick to follow .

#Text=Thus Rolf won the respect , if not the love , of the huge beasts ; more and more they were his charge , and when , on that sad morning , in the last of the barley , Van came in , “ Ach , vot shall I do !
#Text=Vot shall I do !
#Text=Dot Buck ox be nigh dead . ”
#Text=Alas !
#Text=there he lay on the ground , his head sometimes raised , sometimes stretched out flat , while the huge creature uttered short moans at times .
#Text=Only four years before , Rolf had seen that same thing at Redding .
#Text=The rolling eye , the working of the belly muscles , the straining and moaning .
#Text=“ It 's colic ; have you any ginger ? ”
#Text=“ No , I hat only dot soft soap . ”
#Text=What soft soap had to do with ginger was not clear , and Rolf wondered if it had some rare occult medical power that had escaped his mother .
#Text=“ Do you know where there 's any slippery elm ? ”
#Text=“ Yah . ”
#Text=“ Then bring a big boiling of the bark , while I get some peppermint . ”
#Text=The elm bark was boiled till it made a kettleful of brown slime .
#Text=The peppermint was dried above the stove till it could be powdered , and mixed with the slippery slush .
#Text=Some sulphur and some soda were discovered and stirred in , on general principles , and they hastened to the huge , helpless creature in the field .
#Text=Poor Buck seemed worse than ever .
#Text=He was flat on his side , with his spine humped up , moaning and straining at intervals .
#Text=But now relief was in sight -- so thought the men .
#Text=With a tin dipper they tried to pour some relief into the open mouth of the sufferer , who had so little appreciation that he simply taxed his remaining strength to blow it out in their faces .
#Text=Several attempts ended the same way .
#Text=Then the brute , in what looked like temper , swung his muzzle and dashed the whole dipper away .
#Text=Next they tried the usual method , mixing it with a bran mash , considered a delicacy in the bovine world , but Buck again took notice , under pressure only , to dash it away and waste it all .
#Text=It occurred to them they might force it down his throat if they could raise his head .

#Text=So they used a hand lever and a prop to elevate the muzzle , and were about to try another inpour , when Buck leaped to his feet , and behaving like one who has been shamming , made at full gallop for the stable , nor stopped till safely in his stall , where at once he dropped in all the evident agony of a new spasm .
#Text=It is a common thing for oxen to sham sick , but this was the real thing , and it seemed they were going to lose the ox , which meant also lose a large part of the harvest .
